intro: Carum carvi var. intermedium, commonly known as intermediate caraway, is a variant of the caraway plant native to Central and Eastern Europe. It is a biennial herbaceous plant that typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring slender, branched stems and aromatic leaves. The plant produces small white or pale yellow flowers in umbels, followed by oval, aromatic seeds that are used in culinary and medicinal applications. It thrives in well-drained soils and prefers full sun, often found in meadows and along roadsides. Its botanical characteristics make it a valuable species for both ecological and agricultural purposes.
